documents.title: afternoon summary
text: a survation poll commissioned by better together has given the no side an 8-point lead , once do n't knows are excluded .
christopher chope , a conservative mp , has said that backbenchers could block the plans supported by all three main uk party leaders for further devolution for scotland in the event of a no vote .
alex salmond , scotland 's first minister , has predicted the yes camp will win comfortably .

at a campaign event he said : i 'm afraid that mr cameron and his tory friends in downing street , and their labour frontmen in scotland , are going to get their comeuppance next thursday , because scotland is going to go for yes in very substantial proportions .
rupert murdoch has been visiting scotland to try to gauge the mood in the country ahead of thursday 's vote .
the scotland institute thinktank has said an independent scotland 's need for immigration could make border controls with england inevitable .
( see 4.44pm . )
senior bankers have dismissed claims that independence could trigger a great depression as preposterous '' and disingenuous '' .

as the press association reports , ian blackford , who formerly ran deutsche bank 's operations in scotland and the netherlands , and edward mcdowell , a former risk manager for lloyds banking group , have played down the warnings of their former employers of the risks of independence .
blackford said : this is the bank that failed to forecast the crash in 2008 and what they are saying now is preposterous .
rbs and others have said there is no risk to jobs or investment in scotland .
it is about moving the brass plates and the fact is that this all about the uk government 's panic over the real possibility of it losing the union .
mcdowell , who has nearly 40 years ' experience in the banking sector , said deutsche bank 's claims were disingenuous '' .
they do not take account of scotland 's strong fiscal position or well established institutions and i believe is another example of misleading information .
that 's all from me for today .
thanks for the comments .

documents.title: border controls could become inevitable under independence , says thinktank
text: the snp government is more pro-immigration than the uk government .

that 's partly a factor of demographics , and the fact that scotland 's elderly population is creating a shortage of working-age people , and the snp says immigrants are needed to make up the shortfall .
but a report just out from the scotland institute thinktank , immigration in an independent scotland , says the snp has underestimated the number of immigrants it needs .
it has got two striking lines .
scotland institute says an independent scotland would need 20,000 more immigrants a year than are planned .

dr azeem ibrahim , the thinktank 's executive chairman , explains : on current trends , the population is expected to increase by 2.5 % in the period to 2035 , and 90 % of that increase is expected to come from net immigration .
the snp and the opposition scottish labour and liberal parties are very welcoming to these newcomers , but on our calculations this represents a sizeable shortfall .

just how many immigrants we will need to come to scotland every year from now till 2035 is a complicated issue with many variables : the calculations are dependent on what happens to north sea oil revenues , the overall economic performance of scotland , and changes to tax and benefits policies , among many others .

but assuming all other things remain equal , we will need not a 2.5 % but an 8 % increase in the population of scotland in the next two decades , or in other words , we need 20,000 more immigrants per annum than we are currently expecting .
can scotland attract that many ?
there is nothing to say that this is an impossible task , but it will not be an easy one .
scotland 's yearly net immigration figure in the last decade has been 20,000 .
the majority have come as part of one-off influxes to the uk coinciding with eu enlargement into eastern europe .
but there are no other foreseeable waves of enlargement in the current european climate , and ons projections see net immigration climbing down to around 15,000 per annum in the coming decades .
this is the climate in which an independent scotland would have to double its rate of immigration .
england would eventually insist on border controls because immigration to an independent scotland would be so high , the thinktank suggests .
ibrahim says : an independent scotland and the rest of the uk will find that they need hugely different immigration policies .
and that raises the spectre of the unthinkable : the rest of the uk may not be able or willing to support a common travel area policy with scotland as currently exists between the uk and ireland .
and if that happens , we will see border guards along hadrian 's wall before too long .
that is unthinkable .
but it may well end up being politically inevitable in case scotland becomes independent .
yes scotland is urging young people who are pro-independence to make an effort this weekend to win round their grandparents .

generation yes and national collective , two yes groups , have even created a special campaign pack , under the title yes generations # , that can be used to help them move their older relatives to yes , '' according to yes scotland .
it includes suggestions for writing poems , handwritten letters and other creative ways of engaging in independence chat with their grandparents . ''
they are focusing on grandparents because over-65s are the age group most hostile to independence .
in a statement alex salmond said : this is an inspired campaign and a great excuse to pop round for sunday lunch at your grans .

in addition , there were several thousand spectators , they say .
the event passed off peacefully and there were no arrests , the police add in a statement .
in inverclyde labour has lost control of the council because one of its councillors has left the party over her support for independence .

documents.title: yes scotland says survation poll shows it 's all to play for
text: yes scotland has responded to the survation poll .
this is from a spokesman .
this poll records support for yes at 46.5 per cent , and an icm poll conducted around the same time put yes at 49 per cent .
there is everything to play for , and this will spur on everybody who wants and is working hard for a yes to redouble their efforts .

as we say in response to all the polls , we are working flat out to ensure that we achieve a yes vote , because it 's the biggest opportunity the people of scotland will ever have to build a fairer society and more prosperous economy .

a yes vote is our one opportunity to achieve job-creating powers , protect our nhs from the damaging impact of westminster privatisation and cuts , and ensure that never again do we get tory governments imposed on scotland that we have roundly rejected .

documents.title: tony blair backs the no campaign
text: tony blair has spoken out in support of the union .
according to the bbc , at an event in kiev he said : obviously i hope that scotland votes to stay part of the united kingdom .
blair has generally kept a low profile in this contest .
the last time he spoke out in favour of a new , the snp immediately issued a press release implying he was a war criminal and claiming his intervention was a huge boost for the yes side .
james kelly , a pro-independence blogger , says this poll gives the yes camp their second highest ratings in a telephone poll .

documents.title: tory mp says backbenchers may block westminster plans for more devolution
text: on the week in westminster christopher chope , a conservative mp , said there was no guarantee that the extra powers for scotland promised by david cameron , ed miliband and nick clegg would every get through parliament .
the proposals had not been properly discussed , chope said .
he said they should been put forward some time ago , and offered as an option to scottish voters .

if , for example , the uk parliament had wanted to discuss devo max , then the thing to have done would have been to put forward legislation on devo max two or three years ago so it was on the statute book , and then the scots could have been given the choice in the referendum between independence and devo max that would have been approved by parliament .
chope was then asked if he thought there were enough mps opposed to further devolution to scotland to block cameron 's plans .

chope replied : in isolation i 'm sure there would be , because those powers would be powers for us to scotland but there would n't be any rebalance of the constitution and no discussion on some of the more basic issues that were raised in the mackay report .
how serious is this threat ?
there are two reasons for treating chope 's warning with some caution .
first , cameron is not proposing to legislate before the election anyway .
the timetable agreed by all the main parties is for draft legislation in january , with a bill going through the commons after the general election .
and , second , chope seemed to be referring to conservative mps .
the lib dems are very strongly in favour of further devolution to scotland , and labour is very supportive too .

yet , in a wider sense , chope is clearly onto something , and his interview this morning probably marks the start of the tory ( or parliamentary ) backlash against the plans to push the uk towards a federal model by giving scotland greater powers over tax .

although the three main party leaders signed a joint declaration on this in august , there has been little or no discussion within the parties outside scotland on these plans and - rightly or wrongly - the impression has been created that cameron , miliband and clegg okayed this far-reaching constitutional change in a panic last weekend after one bad yougov poll .
at some point , in the event of no vote , there will have be be legislation in the commons .
and chope ( if he is still in parliament then ) is unlikely to be the only mp with reservations about giving more devolution to scotland but not to england .

documents.title: better together welcomes poll findings
text: here 's blair mcdougall , the better together campaign director , on the poll findings .
this poll suggests that no are in the lead but that the race is far from over .
no-one can afford a protest vote .
any one of us could cast the vote that makes the difference between the uk staying together or breaking apart .
this week employers and retailers have set out the real economic costs of separation .
they have made it clear that jobs will be lost and that prices will rise if there is a yes vote .
when we can have better , safer , faster change as part of the uk , why should we risk the costs of separation .
better , safer , faster change '' is the no campaign 's latest slogan .
gordon bown unveiled it in his glasgow speech last night .

documents.title: poll - details
text: the poll was commissioned by better together .
here are the details from the better together news release .
the full voting figures are 40.8 % yes versus 47.0 % no .
excluding undecided voters survation round the voting intention to 54 % no 46 % yes .
asked to rate their likelihood to vote on a scale of 0-10 , 93.1 % rates themselves a 10 .
the poll also finds that 40 % of voters believe they and their families would be financially worse off compared to 27 % who believe they would be better off .
some notes on the methodology employed by survation .
the telephone poll was a systematic random sample of mobiles and landlines , ordered by key strata to reflect the eligible scottish population .
these strata were , age , sex , local authority , income and employment status .
though the poll managed to reach 1,044 respondents , it has an effective sample size of 927 .
this is due to the sampling strategy employed , which aimed to mitigate some of the biases associated with contacting respondents via landlines .
after interview , households ( landline respondents ) with multiple eligible occupants were asked for a second response within the household .
a kish grid was used to assign the eligible participant at random .
respondents from those households that responded twice were accounted for appropriately in the weighting strategy by applying a factor of 0.5 to both respondent 's weights .
mobile respondents were not asked for a second response .
for 1st household respondents and mobile respondents , only those originally drawn into the sample were invited to to take part in the survey .
other answerers were not interviewed .
call-backs were employed were possible .
the survey was conducted over 48hrs , 10th-12th sep .

documents.title: orange order march - what the participants are saying
text: my colleague severin carrell has been interviewing people taking part in the orange order parade .
for anyone for whom the orange order is a cultural mystery , these comments are very revealing .
here they are .

sharon findlay , 43 , from hamilton brother john stewart memorial lodge 123 , wearing her gold tasselled collarette and a bright summer dress said : we 're basically proud to be british ; proud to be scottish and that 's it .
nothing else .
we need to keep the union .
scotland can not survive without the union , and we want it for another 300 years .
we 're christian , we embrace scotland as a nation but we embrace the uk ; we 're part of the uk .
i do n't think that the no vote has really got this across ; this [ march ] has given ordinary no voters the chance to go out and say 'look at us ' this is the chance to come with us .
do n't be defeated : stand up and say 'we 're proud to be british ' . ''
barbara naismith , 69 , a retired electrical factory catering worker from hamilton , who clutched a sunhat , said : we 're very much a christian organisation and we want to keep our queen .
if the snp gets in , that 's another thing we might lose , that they might try to stop us walking on the queen 's highway as well .
things like that have been getting said . ''

andy nicholls , 51 , a supermarket worker with glasgow cowcaddens dressed in black suit , white shirt and red , white and blue striped tie , said : it has brought a bit of pride back to me ; because everywhere i go you just seem to see yes stuff in windows .
the snp is obviously pushing hard .

i think that they 've got more of a momentum whereas no has said we 'll hold onto what we 've got and are n't maybe as dynamic , but today has seen not just the orange people who support what we 're standing for .
from an orange perspective we 're probably the bottom of the food chain , nobody likes us but we 're certainly in the limelight today .
what i would like to see is a yes vote getting defeated maybe by 3,000 votes , and then we see how many orangemen voted no - and that 's the number that swung it . ''
the orange order today has brought people onto the streets .
we were always going to vote no but now people on the pavements [ watching us ] are going home with no posters , badges , flags and stickers .
maybe people will see that the no support is bigger than we think . ''
tommy , a civil servant from glasgow with glasgow plantation orange lodge , said scotland belonged within the union : see the british army ?
the british army has scottish , english , welsh and irish men in it : did they fight the war under different banners ?
no .
they stood under the one banner . ''
jimmy , another orangeman from glasgow plantation , chipped in : we ca n't sleep walk into independence .
we 're trying to hold onto what we 've got ; we 're just trying to hold on to what we 've built up .
our fathers and grandfathers were n't going to war for separation .
we have the barnett formula [ the treasury system for allocating holyrood 's budget ] , so we 're doing better .
we 're doing great .
separation will mean higher charges for food , telephones .
too much would be hit .
we 're part of the british psyche .
we do n't want to throw it away . ''

documents.title: lunchtime summary
text: thousands of orangemen have march through edinburgh to show their support for the union .

it was described as one of the largest orange order gatherings in the uk in recent years and , even though better together did not endorse the march , and there were fears it could be counter-productive , edward stevenson , grand master of the grand orange lodge of ireland , told a rally that they had a right to be heard , even better together alex salmond , scotland 's first minister , has disassociated the yes campaign from a comment from jim sillars , a former snp deputy leader , about banks and bp facing a day of reckoning '' after a vote for independence .
the day after a yes vote will be a day of celebration for the people , not reckoning for big companies drawn into the no campaign by downing street , '' salmond said .
sillars himself claimed his comments were just a ploy to get the media interested in claims that the no campaign is scaremongering .
salmond has insisted that , for every business leader negative about independence , there is another in favour .
for every supermarket drawn into it , there is a tesco who are properly neutral .
for every negativity from bob dudley of bp there is the positivity of tim martin of wetherspoons .
alistair carmichael , the lib dem scottish secretary , has accused the snp and the yes campaign of using intimidation as their tactic of choice '' .
nicola sturgeon , scotland 's deputy first minister , has claimed that momentum is with the yes campaign .
the yes campaign has been carried along by a flourishing of self-confidence among people in scotland .
that momentum is still growing and will soon become unstoppable , as people reject the downing street-orchestrated campaign to talk scotland down .
the yes campaign says it will have more than 35,000 volunteers on the streets this weekend , manning 473 registered street stalls and delivering 2.6m leaflets .
jim murphy , the labour mp and former scotland secretary , has said claimed the momentum is now with the no side .

speaking in glasgow he said : i think that when the snp has a pipe dream of independence when they were behind in the polls , maybe they thought it was ok not to answer the questions about the pound and pensions but now they believe that they could win surely they have to come forward with the answers about what currency we would use in an independent scotland .
but i get a sense now the momentum has switched back - huge numbers of undecided voters are coming to us .

blair jenkins , the yes scotland chief executive , has dismissed comments from deutsche bank 's chief economist claiming that voting for independence would be a mistake on par with those that led to the great depression .

jenkins said : when someone in a bank talks about worldwide meltdown because five million people in scotland are exercising their right of democracy , their right of self determination i think you can tell at that point that intemperate and wild remarks are coming into this debate .
orangemen have come from all over the uk to take part in the edinburgh march , my colleague libby brooks tells me .
she 's sent me this .
what is striking is how many of the crowd have travelled from england , or ireland , to add their support to the march .
chris thompson , a sales assistant from liverpool , had come by coach from liverpool this morning with the liverpool north end lodge .
it 's just to show support to keep scotland in the union , but it 's down to the scottish people to vote . ''
thomas salkeld , a retired construction worker from carlisle , was here with the abraham acton vc memorial lodge .
he said he was unconvinced by the polls showing a surge in support for independence .
every scot i speak to on the border is voting no . ''
also striking is the extraordinary headgear and other decoration worn by the lodge women .
i 've spotted fascinators in union flag colours , matching orange nail polish and in one case red , white and blue locks .
it 's been a beautiful morning and , as the sun strengthens and the march comes to rest on abbey mount , groups of younger members are heading off to 'get a couple of cans before the bus ' .
it has been a friendly , if fierce , event so far .
let 's hope it stays that way .
and she 's just tweeted this .
libby brooks ( @ libby brooks ) overheard a couple of police assessing the march : `` some loyalist arseholes but in general a major success '' # no # indyref

documents.title: majority of english voters oppose currency union with independent scotland - poll
text: there is an interesting populus poll in today 's daily mail on the views of english voters on independence-related matters .
here are the key findings .
a majority of english voters ( 53 % ) is opposed to a currency union in the event of scottish independence , and only 26 % are in favour .
61 % think scottish mps should be prevented from voting on legislation that does not affect scotland .
48 % support scotland being given more powers in the event of a no vote , while 26 % are opposed .
56 % say the whole of the uk should have been given a vote in the referendum , while 44 % support only scots voting .
51 % say the queen should resist calls to intervene in the referendum debate , while 29 % say she should speak out .
populus interviewed 1,043 english adults online on september 12 for the poll .
a reader points out that the yes scotland tweet i quoted early , mocking the size of the orange order march , did not come from an official account .
i 've taken it down .

documents.title: salmond , sillars and their 'day of reckoning ' row - ewen macaskill 's verdict
text: my colleague ewen macaskill is a former political editor of the scotsman and he has known alex salmond and jim sillars for years .
here 's his take on the day of reckoning '' affair .
alex salmond and former snp deputy leader jim sillars have been at loggerheads for decades .
if all the harsh and negative comments ever made about salmond were put into piles , sillars would easily outstrip all the others .
in the interests of presenting a united front in the run-up to referendum day , the two appeared on a platform together on wednesday .
the herald said it had been the first time for 20 years they had appeared on a platform together .
the forced bonhomie did not last long .

salmond , who has been running a tight and disciplined campaign , will be seething that sillars provided the better together with a gift with his threat of revenge against pro-union businesses after the referendum : 'a day of reckoning ' .
salmond , in his statement , totally disassociates himself as politely as he can from sillars ' remarks .
the best that can be said is that salmond at least pre-empted a flurry of calls from the better together campaign to distance himself from the remarks .

sillars , who started in the labour mp and shifted gradually to the snp , is one of the charismatic figures of scottish politics , one of great speakers , talked about when he was younger as a future labour leader .

what made him popular was his unpredictability , his tendency to take risks , and occasionally make mistakes , the biggest of which came when , disappointed with the 1992 general election result , he branded scots as 90-minute patriots '' .
the 'day of reckoning ' is up there with it .
it is almost as offensive but the timing is much worse .
at last the '90-minute ' patriots ' remark came after an election .

documents.title: carmichael accuses snp of using intimidation as 'tactic of choice '
text: alistair carmichael , the lib dem scottish secretary , said jim sillars ' day of reckoning '' comment illustrated the culture of bullying '' comment .
carmichael was speaking before alex salmond issued his statement disassociated himself from what sillars said .
here 's carmichael 's statement .
he was speaking in orkney , where he is campaigning .
in any campaign people from both sides may overstep the mark .
but in the snp-yes campaign intimidation is the tactic of choice .
over recent days those who have campaigned to protect our uk family of nations have faced heavy , ugly scenes .
shouted down in the streets , backed into shops , requiring police escorts .
the leers and jeers of the nationalist camp are designed to shut down debate and drown out the facts .
and this culture has been allowed to flourish by the snp and it 's leader .

years of cybernats , intolerant of anyone who disagrees with them , trolling innocent people , attacking others like jk rowling , susan boyle and others who say positive things about our united kingdom .
snp ministers warning businesspeople in private to stay out of the debate , then attacking them in public when they speak out .
and we now have the extraordinary threat from the former deputy leader of the snp that pro-uk businesses will face a 'day of reckoning ' if there is a yes vote .
this is the real culture of bullying that exists today .
it is in the snp script to say that this is an extraordinary and invigorating debate .
but for those on the receiving end of their attacks it is intimidating and divisive .
we are into the last week of this campaign now .
alex salmond should show respect to scotland , address bullying where it really exists and call off his dogs .
alistair carmichael jack/ ken jack/demotix/corbis

documents.title: salmond disowns sillars over his 'day of reckoning ' comments
text: alex salmond , scotland 's first minister , has just put out a statement disowning jim sillars ' day of reckoning '' comment about the retaliation banks and bp could face under independence .
he did so politely and tactfully , but , in political terms , it was a slap-down nontheless .
here 's the statement .
jim sillars is a great campaigner who has put aside his personal grief over the loss of his wife margo macdonald to put his heart and soul into galvanising the yes vote .

he is fighting a fine campaign all over scotland - but the day after a yes vote will be a day of celebration for the people , not reckoning for big companies drawn into the no campaign by downing street .
jim was simply trying to express the anger felt by so many people about the revelations that some supermarket statements were orchestrated by the prime minister himself .
however , we must rise above these underhand tory tactics , and be confident of the new spirit in scotland .
the people are showing no signs whatsoever of being cowed .
they are in no mood to be bullied by big westminster government putting pressure on big business to intimidate the people of scotland .
indeed , just the opposite is happening .
we should also remember two things .
one is that many businesses have refused to be pressurised by downing street .
for every supermarket drawn into it , there is a tesco who are properly neutral .
for every negativity from bob dudley of bp there is the positivity of tim martin of wetherspoons .
second , there are now almost 3,000 members of business for scotland led by some of the greatest job creators in the country .
people like jim mccoll do n't just talk about scotland 's prospects .
they transform the position of workers at ferguson 's to save shipbuilding on the lower clyde .
but sillars is still giving inteviews .
he has just finished one on news 24 .
i 'll post quotes from it later .
here 's an audioboo so you can enjoy the sound effects .
the orangemen have just been marching past my edinburgh office '' .

god willing , scotland will still be an integral part of the united kingdom and long may that remain .
i would like to wish you all well in a crucial week for our nation .
scotland must say no .

documents.title: orange order rally - grand master 's speech
text: edward stevenson , grand master of the grand orange lodge of ireland , was the main speaker at the orange order rally this morning .
it is being described as one of the largest orange gatherings in the uk in recent times .
i did not hear the speech , but i 've got a text .
here are the key points .
stevenson said the union was best for everybody '' and that it offered civil liberties for all and special privileges for none '' .
this is an enormous celebration and an awesome expression of our pride in our united kingdom .
as an institution we cherish the union , which offers civil liberties for all and special privileges for none .
our message is simple .
we believe the union is best for everybody .
not just people who are members of the orange order , not just for people from any particular tradition , but better for everybody together .
he said the union allowed people to multiple national allegiances .
the underlying strength of the union is that it is possible to be scottish and patriotic - like it is to be english , welsh and northern irish - without being part of an independent state .
our respective layers of nationality are bound together .
he said people outside scotland wanted it to stay in the union .
our message to the citizens of this great country is that we want you to stay .
you are a vital and essential component , and valued partner , in the united kingdom of great britain and northern ireland .
he rejected suggestions that today 's orange order march was counter-productive .
some have chosen to question the effectiveness of this rally and parade , and in doing so have demonised the orange institution in scotland .

however , those same detractors choose to forget that scottish orangemen are citizens ; they are taxpayers ; they are individuals who follow political debates with interest ; and are actively engaged in their local communities .
they are therefore fully entitled to express their views in a democratic society on such an issue of utmost importance .
it would be inconceivable , as valid stakeholders in this society , not to take part in such a debate .
he said there were strong links between scotland and ulster .

with ulster-scottish connections dating back to the 17th century , there is a strong and unbreakable cultural link , and close affinity , between our two jurisdictions which transcends numerous generations and the north channel dividing us .
those close ties , which emanated from the lowlands of scotland in the early 1600s , have enriched our heritage and traditions , and ensure we have a shared and common identity .
there is an old saying that blood is thicker than water .

for while northern ireland and scotland may be only 13 miles apart at the narrowest point , we are bound together by the many family and genealogical ties and friendships which stretch across the strait .
he said ulster orangemen were repaying the debt they owed to the orange lodge in scotland for helping it oppose home rule in 1914 .
just over 100 years ago this month the grand orange lodge of scotland and its members showed very strong support for unionists in ulster in their opposition to home rule .
indeed , by either signing the covenant or the female declaration , including at greyfriars kirkyard in this city , over 14,000 scotsmen and women publicly pledged to stand by their ulster peers .
a century later , we feel it is appropriate by our presence that we repay that debt and show our unstinting support to you in your time of need .
the orange order rally in edinburgh is just getting underway .
i will have some comments from the grand master 's speech soon .
michael crick ( @ michaellcrick ) grandmasters of the orange order gathered from all over the uk in edinburgh this morning to defend the union my colleague libby brooks is covering the event .
here 's the preview story she wrote about it earlier this week .
as she points out , with 50,000 members and 600 lodges across scotland , the orange order is bigger than any single political party .
the yes campaign says it will have more than 35,000 volunteers on the streets this weekend , manning 473 registered street stalls and delivering 2.6m leaflets .
nicola sturgeon , the scottish deputy first minister , is campaigning in glasgow .
in a statement she said the campaign was being buoyed by a flourishing of self-confidence '' .
the yes campaign has been carried along by a flourishing of self-confidence among people in scotland .
this means we can say with certainty to people still making up their mind : 'let 's do this . '
that momentum is still growing and will soon become unstoppable , as people reject the downing street-orchestrated campaign to talk scotland down .
david cameron 's number 10-inspired scare stories are being knocked down one by one - people simply do not believe them .
scotland is one of the world 's richest countries - wealthier per head than the uk , france and japan .
the great opportunity of independence is that we 'll be able to design an economic policy tailored to our needs so that scotland 's wealth works for the many and not just the few .
nicola sturgeon and alex salmond campaigning in perth yesterday .
mitchell/ jonathan mitchell/demotix/corbis

on the today programme john reid ( now lord reid ) , the labour former scottish secretary , dismissed the claim from alex salmond , jim sillars ( see 10.05am ) and the yes camp generally that business leaders are speaking out against independence because they are being orchestrated by number 10 .
reid said : who is controlling deutche bank ?
you think the british government controls them ?
when you look at jp morgan , do you think the british government is controlling them ?
it does n't stack up .
[ salmond ] claims that every expert is mad , lying or threatening but he can no longer credibly deny these risks .
john reid macleod
the row about whether or not the treasury improperly released information about rbs 's plan to move its registered office in the event of a yes vote refuses to go away .
alex salmond , of course , claims this was a deliberate attempt to undermine the yes campaign .
the bbc 's robert peston has been looking into this .
he was talking about it on the today programme in the 8.10 slot and he has set out his findings in more detail on his blog .
he says it was unusual for the treasury to brief on the conclusions of a board meeting before it was over .
in other words , the treasury was briefing about its plans to relocate before the board had formally decided to release this information .
it is certainly unusual for details of company decisions to be released to the media by the government before those decisions have been made .

however sources at rbs tell me they do not believe that the government was breaching its commitment not to interfere with corporate decision-making and becoming what is known as a shadow director of rbs .
peston says that one rbs shareholder has called for a police investigation , but that the bank itself does not consider that a market abuse took place .
and jim sillars has replied to chuka umunna .
jim sillars ( @ naefear ) @ andrewsparrow @ twitterid thanks for the compliment , copy of my book is on it 's way .
# inplaceoffear and i 'll say yes please to the book .
here 's a review from gerry hassan .
and here 's an extract .
mr sillars ' book is fascinating .
it is a real curate 's egg , buzzing with ideas , eclectism and frustration ( both about scotland and personally ) .
many of the suggestions are a bit dotty ( the robert burns hospital ship ) , but many are interesting , and some even heretical ( such as self-governing state schools ) .
it is in a deeper sense a sign of the scottish times : of a culture , which has awoken to the power of the pamphleteer , both old and new , and the floating of numerous vessels and platforms .
( does that mean sillars backs free schools ? )

documents.title: jim sillars today interview - summary
text: here are the main points from the jim sillars interview on the today programme .
he was being interviewed by sarah montague , and at times he was protesting when she interrupted his lengthy answers to pursue her line of questioning .
on twitter some no supporters are saying the interview was a bit of a disaster ( eg , here and here and here ) , but it sounded okay to me .

sillars said that his language about nationalisation and a day of reckoning '' was just a ploy to attract attention to the charge that businesses like bp are scaremongering about the implications of independence .
( see 9.16am . )
he accused bob dudley , the bp chief executive who issued an anti-independence statement on wednesday , of being an agent of downing street '' .
sillars said he wanted bp shareholders to rein [ him ] him '' .
he is taking part in project fear organised by the prime minister from downing street .
he said that companies that threatened to leave scotland under independence would have to give workers a far longer period '' of notice in an independent scotland .
when it was put to him that this could be two years , he accepted this idea .
the snp 's white paper on independence says the snp would restore a 90-days consultation period for redundancies affecting 100 employees or more .
but it does not mention two years and , given that sillars is not an snp minister , he does not have the authority to pronounce on this .
he accused bbc interviewers of always interrupting yes campaigners .
he said an independent scotland would not be able to nationalise the north sea oil industry because it would not have the expertise .
he challenged standard life to explain how much it would cost them to relocate out of an independent scotland .
that question had not been asked by the media , he said .
he said his comments had turned him into a hate figure for the rightwing press .
one of the things that amuses me this morning is i 've given the scottish daily mail the equivalent of a political orgasm .
they now have two people to hate , myself as well as alex salmdon jim sillars ( right ) with alex salmond earlier this week hackett/reuters
i 've been posting from engravings on the wall of the scottish parliament in edinburgh ( just around the corner from where the guardian is based ) .
today 's is a quote from gerard manley hopkins .
andrewsparrow ( @ andrewsparrow ) engraving on the wall of the scottish parliament luckily there is no sign of wet '' in edinburgh today .

yesterday jim sillars , the former snp deputy leader , caused a stir in the scottish independence referendum campaign by saying there would be a day of reckoning '' for the banks and for bp if scotland voted for independence .
bp would also learn the meaning of nationalisation '' , he said .
this morning , in what is either cleverly-disguised climbdown or a testament to his pr mastery , sillars told the today programme that it was all a ploy to get some media attention he said .
if he had just appealed to bob dudley , the bp chief executive , to stop distorting the facts about north sea oil , he said , no one would have taken any notice .
instead he phrased his objections in language to give the scottish daily mail the equivalent of a poltical orgasm '' .
i used those terms deliberately to get onto programmes like yours .
for us to nationalise bp would be a major problem , one of the problems we have in scotland is we do n't have the ability to nationalise the north sea .
anyone with any knowledge in scotland knows we do n't have the kind of technical knowledge and financial and contractual knowledge of the north sea .
there 's about 570 rigs out there but i 've succeeded in getting onto your prestigous programme .
i will be posting more from the interview later .
otherwise , it is the last weekend of campaiging .
there will be intense campaigning all over scotland .
here are some of the events that have been flagged up to the media .
10am : the orange order holds a pro-union rally in edinburgh .
10.30am : blair jenkins , the yes scotland chief executive , campaigns in rutherglen .
11am : jim murphy and john reid , both labour former scottish secretaries , campaign in glasgow .
